subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: On PALM
msgSnippet: ... I thought we were talking about Unicode.  Unicode doesn t encode ligatures separately, unless they belong to legacy character sets like MacRoman. -- John
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> But that is an extra key, and not a natural one. If you want to type the
> ligature Earth, right now you type one letter on the keyboard. (When
> you are using the ASCII font.)

I thought we were talking about Unicode. Unicode doesn't encode ligatures
separately, unless they belong to legacy character sets like MacRoman.

--
John Cowan cowan@... http://ccil.org/~cowan
"The exception proves the rule." Dimbulbs think: "Your counterexample proves
my theory." Latin students think "'Probat' means 'tests': the exception puts
the rule to the proof." But legal historians know it means "Evidence for an
exception is evidence of the existence of a rule in cases not excepted from."

> But that is an extra key, and not a natural one. If you want to type the 
> ligature Earth, right now  you type one letter on the keyboard. (When 
> you are using the ASCII font.) 

I thought we were talking about Unicode.  Unicode doesn't encode ligatures
separately, unless they belong to legacy character sets like MacRoman.
